member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Dto.Sense.RawText
member.summary: The text as it comes from the source.

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Dto.Sense.Text
member.summary: If is configured to remove markup, this contains the formatted text. The still contains the unformmated text.

member.name: F:MerriamWebster.NET.Parsing.ParseOptions.Default
member.summary: Returns a instance with default settings.

member.name: M:MerriamWebster.NET.Parsing.ParseOptions.#ctor(MerriamWebster.NET.Parsing.AudioFormat,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the class with specified settings.

member.name: M:MerriamWebster.NET.Parsing.ParseOptions.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the class with default settings.

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Parsing.ParseOptions.AudioFormat
member.summary: Specifies the audio format for audio files. Default is mp3.

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Parsing.ParseOptions.SkipAdditionalStems
member.summary: Gets or sets whether to skip parsing of additional stems.
member.remarks: In some cases a bunch of (mostly) unrelated entries can be returned as a list of additional stems. (eg. u√±a will return many entries related to 'una', casa will return many additional entries of combinations of case + another word) Set to true (this is the default), to have those entries filtered out.

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Parsing.ParseOptions.RemoveMarkup
member.summary: Gets or sets whether to remove markup from translations.
member.remarks: Translations are often in a pre-formatted formatting, using some specific markup tokens (eg. "{bc}an ion NH{inf}4{\/inf}{sup}+{\/sup} derived from {a_link|ammonia}"). Set to true (this is the default) to remove the markup (raw value will still be returned as well).

member.name: M:MerriamWebster.NET.Parsing.SynonymsParser.ExtractSynonyms(System.String)
member.summary: Find any synonymns (recognizable by {sx} markup) in the provided input string.
member.returns: Returns any synonyms that are found in the input string.

member.name: T:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.AlternateHeadword
member.summary: An alternate headword is a regional or less common spelling of a headword.

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.AlternateHeadword.ParenthesizedSubjectStatusLabel
member.summary:
A parenthesized subject/status label describes the subject area or regional/usage status (eg, "British") of a headword or other defined term, and is displayed in parentheses.
The parenthesized subject/status label is contained in a .

member.name: T:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.AlternateUndefinedEntryWord
member.summary:
In bilingual dictionaries, an undefined entry word may have multiple forms according to grammatical gender and number.
In digital formats such forms are spelled out, while in space-constrained environments they may be presented in shortened cutback form.
An alternate undefined entry is marked up by aure, and contains an undefined entry word cutback in a urec as well as a spelled-out undefined entry word in a ure.

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.AlternateUndefinedEntryWord.TextCutback
member.summary: Text of undefined entry word cutback form

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.AlternateUndefinedEntryWord.Text
member.summary: Text of undefined entry word spelled-out form

member.name: T:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.AppShortdef
member.summary: A very abbreviated version of the entry that could be used in specialized contexts where a preview or shortened entry view is needed.

member.name: T:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.CognateCrossReference
member.summary: When a headword is a less common spelling of another word with the same meaning, there will be a cognate cross-reference pointing to the headword with the more common spelling.

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.CognateCrossReference.Label
member.summary: Cognate cross-reference label.

member.name: T:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.Conjugation
member.summary: A supplemental verb conjugation section is included in some bilingual dictionary entries. A set of verb conjugations is contained in a cjts.

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.Conjugation.Id
member.summary: An ID identifying the verb tense of the following conjugation fields.

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.Conjugation.Fields
member.summary: Array of one or more conjugation fields, each representing a particular verb form in the tense indicated by .

member.name: T:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.CrossReference
member.summary: When a headword or one of its senses represents a less common spelling or inflected form of another word, the definition is omitted and replaced by a cross-reference pointing to the entry containing detailed definition information. A set of cross-references is contained in an xrs.

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.CrossReference.Text
member.summary: Contains cross-reference text

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.CrossReference.Target
member.summary: Contains ID of cross-reference target

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.CrossReferenceTarget.Label
member.summary: Cognate cross-reference label.

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.CrossReferenceTarget.TargetId
member.summary: When present, use as cross-reference target ID for immediately preceding .

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.CrossReferenceTarget.Target
member.summary: Provides hyperlink text in all cases, and cross-reference target ID when no immediately following .

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.CrossReferenceTarget.SenseNumber
member.summary: Sense number of cross-reference target.

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.DefinedRunOn.ParenthesizedSubjectStatusLabel
member.summary:
A parenthesized subject/status label describes the subject area or regional/usage status (eg, "British") of a headword or other defined term, and is displayed in parentheses.
The parenthesized subject/status label is contained in a .

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.DefinedRunOn.GeneralLabels
member.summary: General labels provide information such as whether a headword is typically capitalized, used as an attributive noun, etc.

member.name: T:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.DefiningText
member.summary: The is the text of the definition or translation for a particular .

member.name: F:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.DefiningTextObjectWrapper.TypeOrText
member.summary: The definition type, or definition text.
member.remarks: The main definition starts with an array of two s: one with : "text", followed by the actual definition text. Additional information is also an array of two s: one with the type (bnw, ca, ri, snote, uns, or vis), followed by a object. In the Spanish-English dictionary, the can contain translations.

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.Definition.VerbDivider
member.summary: The verb divider acts as a functional label in verb entries, introducing the separate sense sequences for transitive and intransitive meanings of the verb.

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.DictionaryEntry.Etymologies
member.summary: An etymology is an explanation of the historical origin of a word. While the etymology contained in an et most typically relates to the headword, it may also explain the origin of a defined run-on phrase or a particular sense.

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.DictionaryEntry.Variants
member.summary: Array of one or more variant objects.

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.DictionaryEntry.AlternateHeadwords
member.summary: Array of one or more alternate headword objects.

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.DictionaryEntry.SubjectStatusLabels
member.summary: A subject/status label describes the subject area (eg, "computing") or regional/usage status (eg, "British", "formal", "slang") of a headword or a particular sense of a headword.

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.DictionaryEntry.GeneralLabels
member.summary: General labels provide information such as whether a headword is typically capitalized, used as an attributive noun, etc.

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.DictionaryEntry.LdLink
member.summary: Undocumented field.

member.name: T:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.DividedSense
member.summary: A may be divided into two parts to show a particular relationship between two closely related meanings. The second part of the sense is contained in a , consisting of a along with a second .

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.DividedSense.Etymologies
member.summary: An etymology is an explanation of the historical origin of a word. While the etymology contained in an et most typically relates to the headword, it may also explain the origin of a defined run-on phrase or a particular sense.

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.DividedSense.SubjectStatusLabels
member.summary: A subject/status label describes the subject area (eg, "computing") or regional/usage status (eg, "British", "formal", "slang") of a headword or a particular sense of a headword.

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.DividedSense.GeneralLabels
member.summary: General labels provide information such as whether a headword is typically capitalized, used as an attributive noun, etc.

member.name: T:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.HeadwordInformation
member.summary: The headword is the word being defined or translated in a dictionary entry. Key headword information is grouped in an hwi object. This includes the headword itself in the member, and may include one or more pronunciations in .

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.HeadwordInformation.ParenthesizedSubjectStatusLabel
member.summary:
A parenthesized subject/status label describes the subject area or regional/usage status (eg, "British") of a headword or other defined term, and is displayed in parentheses.
The parenthesized subject/status label is contained in a .

member.name: T:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.History
member.summary: A word history paragraph provides historical background for a headword.

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.History.ParagraphLabel
member.summary: Heading to display at top of section.

member.name: T:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.Inflection
member.summary: Inflection is the change of form that words undergo in different grammatical contexts, such as tense or number.

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.Inflection.SenseSpecificInflectionPluralLabel
member.summary:
This label provides information on the grammatical number (eg, singular, plural) of an inflection in a particular sense.
A sense-specific inflection plural label is contained in an .

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.Metadata.Id
member.summary: Unique entry identifier within a particular dictionary data set, used in cross-references pointing to the entry. It consists of the headword, and in homograph entries, an appended colon and homograph number

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.Metadata.Highlight
member.summary: If text is "yes", the headword is a key part of English vocabulary that is highlighted in print.

member.name: T:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.MwList
member.remarks: Prefixed List with 'Mw' (Merriam-Webster) to avoid confusion with the BCL class.

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.Pronunciation.Ipa
member.summary: International Phonetic Alphabet pronunciation.

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.Pronunciation.Wod
member.summary: Word-of-the-day pronunciation format.

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.Pronunciation.Sound
member.summary: Audio playback information.

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.Pronunciation.WrittenPronunciation
member.summary: Written pronunciation in Merriam-Webster format.

member.name: T:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.Sense
member.summary: The sense gathers together all content relevant to a particular meaning of a headword or defined run-on phrase.
member.remarks:
The is a key organizational unit of the , and gathers together all content relevant to a particular meaning of a headword. Senses are presented in a numbered series, with further divisions into subsenses identified by lowercase letters and parenthesized numbers. s are organized by part of speech for verb entries: if a verb can be both transitive and intransitive, there will be two verb dividers, one marking the sense sequence for the transitive verb and the other the sense sequence for the intransitive verb.
The main definition section encompasses all of the s and verb dividers vd for a headword. A s groups together the numbered senses (sense and sen) defining particular meanings of the headword. Finally, more complex sense structures are represented by pseq, sdsense, and bs.

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.Sense.SenseNumber
member.summary: The sense number identifies a sense or subsense within the entry. A may contain bold Arabic numerals, bold lowercase letters, or parenthesized Arabic numerals.

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.Sense.SenseSpecificGrammaticalLabel
member.summary:
This label notes whether a particular sense of a verb is transitive (T) or intransitive (I).
The sense-specific grammatical label is contained in an .

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.Sense.Etymologies
member.summary: An etymology is an explanation of the historical origin of a word. While the etymology contained in an et most typically relates to the headword, it may also explain the origin of a defined run-on phrase or a particular sense.

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.Sense.SubjectStatusLabels
member.summary: A subject/status label describes the subject area (eg, "computing") or regional/usage status (eg, "British", "formal", "slang") of a headword or a particular sense of a headword.

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.Sense.Synonyms
member.summary: A thesaurus entry typically contains a list of synonyms for the headword.

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.Sense.RelatedWords
member.summary: A thesaurus may contain a list of words related to the headword. A related word list is contained in .

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.Sense.GeneralLabels
member.summary: General labels provide information such as whether a headword is typically capitalized, used as an attributive noun, etc.

member.name: T:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.SenseSequence
member.summary: The sense sequence contains a series of senses and subsenses, ordered by sense numbers beginning at Arabic numeral "1".

member.name: T:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.Supplemental
member.summary: A supplemental verb conjugation section is included in some bilingual dictionary entries. A set of verb conjugations is contained in a .

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.Supplemental.Conjugations
member.summary: Array of one or more objects.

member.name: T:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.Target
member.summary: Matching target entry in other Merriam-Webster data set.

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.Target.Identifier
member.summary: Target entry universally unique identifier.

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.Target.Source
member.summary: Target entry source data set.

member.name: T:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.UndefinedRunOn
member.summary:
An undefined entry word is derived from or related to the headword, carries a functional label and possibly other information, but does not have any definitions.
A set of s can follow (or "run on" from) the entry's main def definition section, with each such run-on containing an .

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.UndefinedRunOn.EntryWord
member.summary: Undefined entry word

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.UndefinedRunOn.ParenthesizedSubjectStatusLabel
member.summary:
A parenthesized subject/status label describes the subject area or regional/usage status (eg, "British") of a headword or other defined term, and is displayed in parentheses.
The parenthesized subject/status label is contained in a .

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.UndefinedRunOn.GeneralLabels
member.summary: General labels provide information such as whether a headword is typically capitalized, used as an attributive noun, etc.

member.name: T:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.Variant
member.summary: A variant is a different spelling or styling of a headword, defined run-on phrase, or undefined entry word.

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.Variant.VariantLabel
member.summary: Variant label, such as ‚Äúor‚Äù (optional).

member.name: P:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.Variant.Cutback
member.summary: Contains a cutback form of the preceding variant
member.remarks: A variant is often a sense-specific idiom or phrase containing the headword. In space-constrained environments, such variants may be presented in a shortened cutback form that omits the headword itself. A variant cutback is contained in a .

member.name: T:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.WordSubjectStatusLabel
member.summary: A thesaurus subject/status label describes the subject area (eg, "computing") or regional/usage status (eg, "British", "formal", "slang") of a synonym, antonym, or other word listed in a thesaurus entry.

member.name: T:MerriamWebster.NET.Response.WordVariant
member.summary: A thesaurus word variant is a variant spelling of a synonym, antonym, or other word listed in a thesaurus entry.
